content.description: Many ways up this one. Be mindful of some loose blocks, although I did clear some already. A bit dirty but fun movement.
content.protection: Standard rack, trees at top for anchor or TR
content.location: To the left of the roof maybe 30 ft

content.description:
Follow the center crack up and through the roof skirting around the roof on the left side. Above this is sustained crimpy holds with occasional horizontal jugs for gear.

 Left variation: Climb the face and avoid the main dihedral/crack, slightly easier, but is runout pretty much until the roof.

 Right variation: Follow the mini dihedral around the roof on the right. Also slightly easier, but more moss and dirt.
content.protection: Trees and rock at top for (TR) anchor . Standard rack gets it done.  One rusted bolt halfway up slab portion.
content.location: Center crack in little roof section.

content.description: The obvious small dihedral in the middle of the Big Wall.  This route starts at the bottom of the dihedral.  Stem up using good feet and hands for about 20 feet until the dihedral turns into a hands crack.  Use the crack and face to get out of the dihedral and do some face moves to the top.
content.protection: Medium nuts, small to medium cams.
content.location: This starts in the middle of the Big Wall.

content.description: This route ascends the slabby face on the climbers right of the Big Wall.
content.protection: When I climbed it I TR'd it but you could probably find some pro.
content.location: Right side of the Big Wall.

content.description:
The Roadside crag had two big features - the Big Wall and a smaller but still big feature to the climbers right of this. 

  This feature - the Big Wall - has routes in the 30-60ft range on good quality (but sometimes dirty rock).
